content:
ass="word-wrap-span">This piece is from 1843 , our sister magazine of ideas, lifestyle and culture. It was published in the ass="word-wrap-span">August/ass="word-wrap-span">September 2019 issue.

A ass="word-wrap-span">BLURRY ass="word-wrap-span">IMAGE of tiny morsels of falafel – mid-fry – flashes up on my phone, accompanied by a text apologising for ass="word-wrap-span">The quality of ass="word-wrap-span">The photo. “ass="word-wrap-span">Did you get it?” asks Wafaa Saad, a moass="word-wrap-span">Ther of six, from Gaza ass="word-wrap-span">City. “ass="word-wrap-span">The connection is weak. ass="word-wrap-span">The electriass="word-wrap-span">City keeps going in and out.” ass="word-wrap-span">Two symmetrical plates of falafel, delectable fritters formed from chickpeas, fresh dill, chillies and coriander, are surrounded by olives, pickled peppers, shatta, a local chilli-pepper paste, sliced tomatoes and cucumbers. “ass="word-wrap-span">Dinner!”

ass="word-wrap-span">Most pictures that come out of Gaza are of ass="word-wrap-span">The devastation wreaked by Israeli bombardment and ass="word-wrap-span">The grinding poverty of life under Israel’s and ass="word-wrap-span">Egypt’s blockade of ass="word-wrap-span">The territory. ass="word-wrap-span">The 360 square-kilometre sliver of land, wedged between ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Sinai ass="word-wrap-span">Peninsula and Israel, is crowded with 2m people, ass="word-wrap-span">Most of whom don’t consider Gaza ass="word-wrap-span">Their ass="word-wrap-span">ancestral home. ass="word-wrap-span">Around 80% are refugees from oass="word-wrap-span">Ther parts of ass="word-wrap-span">Palestinian territories. ass="word-wrap-span">The small photo of falafel is a reminder that, even in desperate circumstances, people need to eat.

Gaza’s cuisine is part of the culinary continuum of the ass="word-wrap-span">Levant. It has much in common with nearby Jordan, ass="word-wrap-span">Lebanon and ass="word-wrap-span">Syria, but it now exists in a gastronomical bubble, cut off from all its neighbours.

In 1976 my parents left Gaza for ass="word-wrap-span">Kuwait, where I was born. We returned to Gaza only for hot summers. ass="word-wrap-span">Today, visiting from my home in ass="word-wrap-span">America is impossible. ass="word-wrap-span">Food is one of the few ways in which my Gazan roots continue to play out. In my suburban kitchen in ass="word-wrap-span">Maryland I cook the ass="word-wrap-span">Food of my parents’ birthplace and taste our heritage.

In Gaza you can eat your way through ass="word-wrap-span">The riches of ass="word-wrap-span">Palestinian history: kishik is a fermented wheat and dairy stew once made in Beit Tima, a ass="word-wrap-span">Palestinian-Arab village depopulated during ass="word-wrap-span">The 1948 Arab-Israeli war, and oass="word-wrap-span">Ther farming communities. ass="word-wrap-span">Richly spiced shrimp is from Jaffa. ass="word-wrap-span">Lamb is roasted long and slow as ass="word-wrap-span">The nomadic Naqab ass="word-wrap-span">Bedouin have cooked it for centuries. ass="word-wrap-span">The blisteringly hot tomato and dill salad is from Gaza itself.

ass="word-wrap-span">Today half of Gaza’s population live in poverty and two-thirds either can’t afford or don’t have access to nutritious food in sufficient quantities. ass="word-wrap-span">More than half are unemployed. To cope, local women say they buy cheap foods in small quantities, often with borrowed money, and cook it over firewood. Saad sends me a photo of her fridge: it is mostly empty, the few items on the shelves melting or rotting because of power outages.

Saad’s husband is employed by ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Palestinian ass="word-wrap-span">National ass="word-wrap-span">Authority, ass="word-wrap-span">The body that has governed Gaza since 1994, and works in public health. His salary has been cut but because he has a job his family receives no food aid. ass="word-wrap-span">They live pay cheque to pay cheque, yet Saad considers her family (pictured above) is among ass="word-wrap-span">The lucky ones. ass="word-wrap-span">She plans ass="word-wrap-span">The rare costly dish ingredient by ingredient, ass="word-wrap-span">She says. ass="word-wrap-span">This week ass="word-wrap-span">She has makhshi koosa in her sights: fried magda squash stuffed with spiced ground beef and pine-nuts in a fresh tomato sauce. ass="word-wrap-span">She will buy ass="word-wrap-span">The vegetables, ass="word-wrap-span">Then wait until ass="word-wrap-span">She has ass="word-wrap-span">The money to buy a little beef. “ass="word-wrap-span">Maybe Friday...”

ass="word-wrap-span">For Saad, thinking about and planning ass="word-wrap-span">Her family’s favourite diass="word-wrap-span">Shes is a ass="word-wrap-span">Form of escapism. ass="word-wrap-span">Her husband loves fatteh, poached and stuffed chicken served on top of cinnamon-flecked rice and saj, buttery griddle bread, with a dressing of smaass="word-wrap-span">Shed green chilli peppers, garlic and lemon juice, as well as maqlooba, literally “upside-down”: a layered, spiced rice dish with chicken and aubergines, cooked then dramatically flipped onto a tray. ass="word-wrap-span">She makes them once or twice a year at most. Gaza sits on the coast but fish is a rarity: the good fish goes to restaurants ass="word-wrap-span">For journalists, aid workers and Gaza’s elite.

Iman Joudeh, a single moass="word-wrap-span">Ther, runs a women’s cooking co-opera­tive in ass="word-wrap-span">The central Gazan town of Deir Al-Balah. It employs more than ten women, all ass="word-wrap-span">The breadwinners of ass="word-wrap-span">Their families, to prepare meals for wealthier Gazans to buy. ass="word-wrap-span">They specialise in local dishes: spiced, hand-rolled couscous, served with a stew of chickpeas and orange squash; kunafa arabiyya, a sweet pastry made elsewhere with cheese but in Gaza with walnuts.

As I listen to Joudeh, my mouth waters as I remember ass="word-wrap-span">The flavours of a home I can no longer visit. I try to replicate ass="word-wrap-span">Them thousands of miles away but I wonder, in ass="word-wrap-span">The birthplace of ass="word-wrap-span">These recipes, how ass="word-wrap-span">The co-operative is able to prepare ass="word-wrap-span">Them. ass="word-wrap-span">The difficulty is affording ass="word-wrap-span">The ingredients, says Joudeh.

In the eyes of many, musakhan is the national dish of ass="word-wrap-span">Palestine. ass="word-wrap-span">Chicken is rubbed with sumac, cinnamon and ass="word-wrap-span">allspice and served on top of flatbread baked in a clay oven, then drenched in rich, fruity olive oil and smothered with caramelised onions and fried ass="word-wrap-span">almonds. It appears in my dreams. ass="word-wrap-span">But in Gaza, says Joudeh, fresh ass="word-wrap-span">Chicken is so expensive that people use frozen, imported meat, which lacks flavour ass="word-wrap-span">But is half the price.

ass="word-wrap-span">Such thriftiness is widespread. Um Mazen and her husband run a small supermarket (pictured above) in norass="word-wrap-span">Thern Gaza. ass="word-wrap-span">Their customers’ children stare longingly at ass="word-wrap-span">The snack ass="word-wrap-span">aisle. ass="word-wrap-span">Shoppers buy grains only when ass="word-wrap-span">They receive ass="word-wrap-span">Their quarterly food vouchers from aid groups. ass="word-wrap-span">They buy olive oil by ass="word-wrap-span">The shekel’s worth, enough for a single dish.

ass="word-wrap-span">That ass="word-wrap-span">Olive oil is unaffordable is especially bitter. ass="word-wrap-span">Olive trees are ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Most lasting symbol of ass="word-wrap-span">Palestine. ass="word-wrap-span">Alass="word-wrap-span">Most half of Gaza’s fertile land lies along its border with Israel. ass="word-wrap-span">The strip was once thick with ass="word-wrap-span">Olive groves but ass="word-wrap-span">The Israeli army has levelled well over a thousand ass="word-wrap-span">acres of ass="word-wrap-span">Them. ass="word-wrap-span">Most locals rarely use ass="word-wrap-span">The expensive oil now; ass="word-wrap-span">They have replaced it with sunflower or soybean oil, doled out sparingly by aid agencies.

Saad sends me a message to tell me that she was at last able to cook her beloved makhshi koosa for her family, “but everyone devoured it before I could send you a picture!” It is a small but important victory in a world where ass="word-wrap-span">There is little semblance of normality. ass="word-wrap-span">The mundane routines that Gazans keep – preparing traditional meals with whatever is available, eating togeass="word-wrap-span">Ther whenever possible, telling ass="word-wrap-span">Their stories – are acts of quiet resistance.

Laila Elhaddadis ass="word-wrap-span">The co-author of “ass="word-wrap-span">The Gaza ass="word-wrap-span">Kitchen: A ass="word-wrap-span">Palestinian ass="word-wrap-span">Culinary ass="word-wrap-span">Journey”
